questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented to the emergency department with Upper abdominal pain radiating to the back. On X-ray, the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Clinical feature of upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, along with the X-ray showing colon cutoff sign, is suggestive of Acute Pancreatitis.
  • Imaging features of Acute Pancreatitis include enlarged Pancreas with peripancreatic inflammatory changes, duct dilatation & acute fluid collections.
  • Other Radiological signs seen in Acute Pancreatitis are :
    • Gasless abdomen (due to repeated vomiting)
    • Sentinel Loop sign (Non-specific)
    • Small bowel ileus
    • Renal Halo sign on CT Scan
    • Colon cut off sign

Renal Halo sign

Explanation of other options:

Acute Cholecystitis (Option A) presents with RUQ pain typically after Meals and radiologically shows Gallbladder dilatation, gallstone obstructing the neck of GB, wall thickening, sonographic Murphy's sign.

Small Bowel Obstruction (Option B) presents with diffuse abdominal pain and radiologically shows Stepladder Pattern.

Hollow viscus perforation (Option D) presents with diffuse abdominal pain with shock and has the “Air under diaphragm” sign. The management is resuscitation followed by laparotomy.

Hollow viscus perforation

questions.text: Identify the structure marked and the name of the radiological procedure performed from the given image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image is a Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) scan.
  • The arrows are pointing to the pancreatic duct, which appears as a linear high-signal-intensity structure on MRCP.
  • MRCP is a non-invasive imaging modality where bile and pancreatic secretions act as natural contrast.
  • No external contrast is required in MRCP.

Explanation of other options:

MRCP and Common bile duct (Option A): The structure is not the common bile duct, which would be more anterior and medial.

ERCP and Cystic duct (Option C): ERCP uses contrast and fluoroscopy, not used here.

ERCP and Hepatic ducts(Option D): Hepatic ducts would appear more branched in the hepatic hilum region.

questions.text: A 29-year-old Rahul presented with abdominal pain for the last 5 days. He was advised to undergo a CT scan of the abdomen. On CT, it showed the presence of multiple dilated pancreatic ducts with side branch dilatations. The ducts were found to be communicating with each other. What is the probable diagnosis based on the findings given?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical history of abdominal pain and CT scan findings of multiple pancreatic cysts with dilatation of the main duct are concerning for the main type of IPMN.
  • Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms or tumours (IPMNs or IMPTs) are epithelial pancreatic cystictumours of mucin-producing cells that arise from the pancreatic ducts. They are most commonly seen in elderly patients.
  • On imaging, particularly MRCP, they are characterised by single or multiple unilocular or septated pancreatic cystic lesions communicating with the pancreatic ducts.

Explanation of other options:

Serous cystadenoma pancreas (Option B): Multiple, microcystic, honeycomb appearance with a Cluster of grapes without any connection to the pancreatic duct, with characteristic Sunburst appearance with a central stellate scar with calcification.

Mucinous cystadenoma of the Pancreas (Option C) appears as a single unilocular cyst filled with mucin.

Pancreas pseudocyst (Option D)  is seen in cases of Chronic Pancreatitis. Post-pancreatitis collection without epithelial lining, no ductal communication.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with abdominal pain came to the OPD for follow-up. A radiograph was taken, and the following findings were seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given radiograph shows dilatation and beading of the pancreatic duct, often with intraductal calcifications, which could give a 'chain of lakes' appearance in chronic pancreatitis.
  • The X-ray shows multiple coarse calcifications in the mid-abdomen over the expected site of the pancreas.
  • These are classic for pancreatic ductal calcifications, a hallmark of chronic pancreatitis.
  • Chronic inflammation leads to fibrosis and calcification of the pancreatic ducts, commonly due to long-term alcohol use or genetic predisposition.

Explanation of other options:

Renal Stones (Option A)  typically present with colicky abdominal pain and don't show Chain of Lakes appearance.

Acute Pancreatitis (Option B): Radiological signs includes Gasless abdomen (due to repeated vomiting), Sentinel Loop sign (Non-specific), Colon cut off sign, Small bowel ileus, Renal Halo sign on CT Scan

Gallstones (Option D) it shows the Mercedes-Benz sign.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, anorexia and weight loss. A barium study was performed, and the following findings were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The above clinical Scenario and radiological image are suggestive of Pancreatic Head Carcinoma.
  • The above radiological image shows the Reverse 3 sign of Frostberg.
  • It is a non-specific sign, also seen in Chronic pancreatitis.

Other radiological signs seen in Pancreatic Head Carcinoma are : 

  • Antral pad sign
  • Widening of the C-shape loop of the Duodenum
  • Mucosal irregularity: Rose thorn of the medial wall of the 2nd part of the medial wall
  • Double duct sign

Explanation of other options:

Acute pancreatitis (Option B) shows an Enlarged pancreas with peripancreatic inflammatory changes, duct dilation & acute fluid Collections.

CBD stone (OptionC) shows a Double-barrel sign in USG, not in CT imaging.

Chronic Pancreatitis (Option D)  has a Chain of Lakes appearance on CT and X-ray.
